ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a deep understanding of Michel Montaigne's work and philosophy. I was able to think critically about specific passages and draw common themes, and got to write a cool essay about multiple texts!
I learned about Montaigne's ideas about philosophy, and his Essais.
I developed a clear understanding of Montaigne and his works. It was a difficult text to follow, but we got through it well.

This course offered an in depth look into the essays of Michel de Montaigne. I learned how to differentiate between academic and Pyrrhonian skepticism, how cultural relativity fits within a philosophical framework, and what to make out of self reflection. More broadly, this class helped bolster my confidence in spoken French and exposed me to an unfamiliar style of written French.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course are the deep knowledge of the professor. She is such an expert on Montaigne's life and work! It's amazing. It could be improved by being shortened, as 2 hours felt too long to focus.

Strengths: the course was very relaxed, and didn't require a lot of engagement besides the required assignments to do well in the class. The assessments built off each other as we had the option to develop the same topic from a presentation, short paper and final paper. Weaknesses: this relaxed nature meant that I found myself pretty disengaged with the course. Montaigne is a difficult read, and I think to really love this class you have to really love Montaigne. I closely read the Essai that I did my assignments on, but as for the rest it was much more variable. The course could be improved by starting with a bit more background about Montaigne, and about philosophy in general. I think it was assumed that we knew the theories of the ancient Greek schools of thought, and they were integrated into the course around nine weeks in. It would have been better to introduce these theories, and how Montaigne developed and contradicted this tradition, much earlier in the course.

The course was well structured and engaging. Montaigne is a fascinating author and Mme. Brancher provided the necessary tools for us to understand his text. One comment that I would make is that I would have liked to look at more Essais during the course.

Strengths: Madame Brancher is a wonderful professor, whom you can tell is fiercely dedicated to the course's topic; the class is well-structured and accessible to a diversity of French levels
Weaknesses: we often went over class time, but it always happened when Madame was really immersed in a particular lecture

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the COVID-19 adjustments didn't really affect the running of the course. It was a shame we couldn't visit the Beinecke.
If this class, for some reason, continued online, I would suggest a 5 minute break for people to rest their eyes from looking at their screen.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who loves philosophy and loves reading Montaigne. I think most other students will struggle a bit.
Yes, very interesting course about a fascinating author. The course was fun and I enjoyed discussing with the other students. Mme. Brancher is also a great professor!

I would! The class appears daunting on paper, but the coursework is not overwhelming and the topic is really interesting. I couldn't say I had any particular desire to learn about skepticism, but this course managed to explore complicated philosophical stances in a manageable manner. I can now say I actually understand skepticism and a good deal of what Montaigne wished to accomplish in publishing his personal accounts of subjects ranging between God, gender, reasoning, and politics.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
